parts.text:
This document reveals an email exchange where Dr. Vanessa Teague and Prof. Andrew Conway, acting as independent citizens and experts, inform the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) of a critical error in its Senate counting software, noting its deviation from the Electoral Act. They offer their own open-source implementation as a solution and volunteer to assist in correcting the AEC's official code, advocating for greater transparency through ballot audits.

From an Objectivist perspective, this interaction starkly highlights the conflict between individual reason and bureaucratic opacity. Teague and Conway exemplify the virtue of reason and productive achievement, having independently identified a systemic flaw and developed a rational solution (their 'ConcreteSTV' software). Their initiative demonstrates the power of individual intellect in seeking truth and ensuring system integrity, aligning with individualism's emphasis on independent thought and action. Their willingness to offer their open-source code and expertise, while commendable as voluntary assistance, also exposes an implicit expectation of forced altruism, as productive citizens are compelled to identify and fix government failures pro bono.

Conversely, the AEC's conduct contradicts these values. The existence of a legally non-compliant algorithm in its closed-source software signifies a failure of reason within the bureaucracy, relying on an unpredictable and unaccountable system. The AEC's use of closed-source software and its implied resistance to openly publishing its code represent a profound bureaucratic obstacle and a suppression of productive achievement. By not openly embracing independent verification and collaboration, the AEC creates an environment where essential system integrity is reliant on external, uncompensated scrutiny rather than internal transparency and the leveraging of free enterprise principles through competitive innovation or open collaboration. This subverts the government's legitimate function of protecting individual liberties by failing to provide a transparent and objective framework for electoral processes.

prompt:
From an Objectivist perspective, summarize this specific document within the context of the FOI request. Analyze how the document reflects or contradicts the values of reason, individualism, and free enterprise. Note any evidence of bureaucratic obstacles, forced altruism, or suppression of productive achievement.

To aid you, the overview of the FOI request is: [REQUEST OVERVIEW START] These FOI documents starkly illustrate how individual initiative, driven by rational self-interest and productive achievement, stands in sharp contrast to government overreach and opacity. Private citizens, by independently developing verification software and rigorously analyzing electoral processes, exemplified the virtue of reason in seeking truth and ensuring system integrity. Conversely, the government's use of closed-source software, systemic errors, and the deliberate suppression of information by the AEC represent a profound violation of individual rights, transparency, and the rule of law. Such bureaucratic actions actively undermine personal freedom and productive achievement by creating an unpredictable, unaccountable system, thereby subverting the government's sole legitimate function: the protection of individual liberties through a transparent and objective framework.
 [REQUEST OVERVIEW END] 

--- MAIN DOCUMENT TEXT START ---



--- Page 1 ---

From:
To:
Cc:
Subject:
Date:
Attachments:

Kristen Wild
Vanessa Teague
andrewstvcount@greatcactus.org; Tom Rogers; Thomas Ryan
RE: Corrections to the Senate Counting algorithm [SEC=OFFICIAL]
Tuesday, 19 October 2021 11:28:00 AM
18 10 2021 - Dr Andrew Conway and Prof. Vanessa teague - Senate Counting and Scrutiny.pdf
image001.gif
image002.gif
image003.jpg

Good morning

Please find the attached response from Mr Rogers.

Regards
Kristen

Kristen Wild | Personal Assistant to the Commissioner
Executive Leadership Team
Australian Electoral Commission

From: Vanessa Teague <Vanessa.Teague@anu.edu.au> 
Sent: Tuesday, 31 August 2021 3:40 PM
To: Tom Rogers 
Cc: andrewstvcount@greatcactus.org
Subject: Corrections to the Senate Counting algorithm

; Thomas Ryan 

CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the Australian Federal Government. Do not click links
or open attachments unless you recognise the sender and know the content is safe.

Dear Mr Rogers and Mr Ryan,

Please find attached our report on the AEC's Senate count.

We have found one instance in which the software breaks ties in a way that is not what is
specified in the Electoral Act. We have also noted some other ambiguities that need to be
resolved either by amending the Act or by otherwise committing to the exact counting
algorithm.

We would be very happy to help you correct the code - you can see our implementation here
https://github.com/AndrewConway/ConcreteSTV.  We could easily make the necessary
adjustments to the official code if it was similarly published online.

Also, we support recent proposals to audit randomly selected paper ballots at the end of the
digitizing process to give everyone evidence of the accuracy of the process. We would be
happy to help the AEC implement these measures securely and transparently.

Yours Sincerely,

Vanessa Teague and Andrew Conway.

Vanessa Teague


--- Page 2 ---

CEO, Thinking Cybersecurity Pty. Ltd.

A/Prof (Adj.), Research School of Computer Science
The Australian National University | Canberra ACT 2601
E: vanessa.teague@anu.edu.au

W: https://researchers.anu.edu.au/researchers/teague-v

CRICOS Provider #00120C

Provide only the markdown formatted summary text. Do not include any conversational filler or preamble.
